H0.text: Plant growth is the most likely occurrence that causes the area of a small ocean island to shrink slowly.

H1.text: Beach erosion is the most likely occurrence causing the area of a small ocean island to slowly shrink.

H2.text: Dissolving rock is the occurrence most likely responsible for the slow shrinking area of a small ocean island.

H3.text: Falling water is the most likely cause of the slow shrinking of the area of a small ocean island.

A4.text: Coastal erosion is the loss or displacement of land, or the long-term removal of sediment and rocks along the coastline due to the action of waves, currents, tides, wind-driven water, waterborne ice, or other impacts of storms.

A5.text: Solution is the process in which acids contained in sea water will dissolve some types of rock such as chalk or limestone.

A6.text: The rate at which cliff fall debris is removed from the foreshore depends on the power of the waves crossing the beach.

A7.text: Coastal erosion has been greatly affected by the rising sea levels globally.
